[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/update/build_updater()] [Draft release installation] Can draft or unpublished releases be installed if their tag is known, bypassing normal release validation? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/update/get_path()] [Relative path exploitation] Lines 93-96 construct paths by joining with binary_name - can relative paths in binary_name escape the installation directory? (High)
[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/update/get_path()] [Case sensitivity issues] On case-insensitive filesystems, can attackers substitute 'Binary' for 'binary' to bypass checks? (Low)
[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/update/get_path()] [Unicode path handling] Can Unicode paths with special characters cause issues in path comparison or filesystem operations? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/update/build_updater()] [HOME/USERPROFILE injection] Line 54 calls get_additional_binaries_dir() which uses HOME/USERPROFILE environment variables - can attackers manipulate these to redirect installations? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/update/get_path()] [Cross-platform path issues] Line 93 calls get_additional_binaries_dir() which returns platform-specific paths - can path separator differences cause vulnerabilities? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/update/build_updater()] [Build-time tampering] Line 41 uses cli_build_information() which is embedded at compile time - can attackers tamper with build artifacts to inject malicious build info? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/update/build_updater()] [BUILD_OS constant manipulation] Line 42 uses BUILD_OS constant - if this is modified in the build process, can it cause installation of wrong platform binaries? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/update/build_updater()] [Insecure defaults] The Update::configure() at line 67 may have insecure defaults - are TLS verification, timeout, and retry settings secure? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/update/build_updater()] [Builder pattern vulnerabilities] Lines 67-77 use builder pattern - can certain call orders or missing required fields cause security issues? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/update/build_updater()] [Error context leakage] Lines 42, 57, 77 add context to errors - can error messages leak sensitive information about filesystem structure or configuration? (Low)
[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/update/build_updater()] [Partial failure states] If create_dir_all succeeds but updater build fails, is the filesystem left in a partially initialized state? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/update/get_path()] [Binary execution without validation] The function returns paths that will presumably be executed - is there any validation that binaries are safe before execution? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/update/get_path()] [Environment variable precedence] Line 88 checks environment variable first - can this be abused to override legitimate installations with malicious binaries? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/update/build_updater()] [Compromised GitHub account] If the GitHub account specified by repo_owner is compromised, malicious releases would be auto-installed - is there additional verification? (Critical)
[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/update/build_updater()] [Repository transfer attack] If the GitHub repository is transferred to a malicious owner, can updates be hijacked? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos/src/update/build_updater()] [Tag deletion and recreation] Can attackers delete and recreate version tags with malicious binaries after legitimate ones are published? (High)
